conclusion: Analyze forces on hemispheres to find dynamic friction coefficient.
Hemispheres A and B are between vertical walls, with a 30° angle between the line connecting their centers and the horizontal.
Hemisphere A has weight \( W_A = m \cdot g \), normal force \( N_A \), and frictional force \( f_A \).
Hemisphere B has weight \( W_B = 2m \cdot g \), normal force \( N_B \), and frictional force \( f_B \).
Frictional forces balance components of normal forces to prevent sliding.
Resolve forces for Hemisphere A using 30° angle.
Horizontal component of \( N_A \) is \( N_A \cos(30^\circ) \), vertical component is \( N_A \sin(30^\circ) \).
Frictional force \( f_A \) balances horizontal component of weight of B: \( f_A = N_A \cos(30^\circ) \).
Resolve forces for Hemisphere B: \( N_B = W_B = 2mg \).
Frictional force \( f_B \) balances horizontal component of weight of A: \( f_B = mg\sqrt{3} \).
Relate frictional forces to dynamic friction coefficient: \( f_A = \mu_{\text{dynamic}} N_A \).
Equilibrium condition for A: \( N_A \cos(30^\circ) = \mu_{\text{dynamic}} N_A \).
